critique: The document reflects President Roosevelt's approval of an agreement within the construction industry, specifically the Painting, Paperhanging, and Decorating Division in Rochester, Minnesota, under the National Industrial Recovery Act of 1933. This act was a cornerstone of FDR's New Deal, aimed at combating the Great Depression through government intervention in the economy. The agreement likely involves setting standards for fair competition, wages, and working conditions within the industry. The document emphasizes compliance with federal regulations and the authority of the National Industrial Recovery Board.
